Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Environmental Modulation, Osmosensitivity and Signaling in a Model Osmoreceptor
Award.AbstractNarration:
The regulation of salt and water balance, or osmoregulation, is fundamental to the proper function of the molecules that carry on the business of life in living organisms. This project addresses the gap in knowledge of how osmotic balance is monitored and how an organism responds to any deviation from the optimal state. Detection of a change in this critical balance by osmoreceptor cells is the first step in activating the mechanisms which ensure osmotic balance is restored and maintained. Nevertheless, our understanding of how osmoreceptor cells work has been hindered by their complex structure and arrangement among other cells in the brain, kidney and other organs. This makes it extremely difficult to develop useful experimental approaches. The prolactin cell of the tilapia solves this problem. Prolactin is an osmoregulatory hormone in tilapia, a remarkable fish that can live in fresh water and in salinities exceeding that of seawater. Unlike mammals, prolactin cells in tilapia are arranged into a nearly homogeneous mass in the pituitary gland making it easy to study how the cell is regulated. Prolactin cells have been shown to function as osmoreceptors that respond directly to osmotic changes by altering prolactin secretion which restores osmotic balance. An increase in cell size is the trigger that activates cell mechanisms that increase prolactin secretion. This project will investigate how cell size controls the activity/expression of the gene that encodes prolactin. It is anticipated that this work will increase the fundamental understanding of how osmoreceptor cells work in an economically important food fish grown in fresh water and seawater.

This project will allow the recruitment, education, and training of high school, undergraduate and graduate students, including those of under-represented minorities from within our multi-ethnic, culturally diverse, University and area schools. Progress will be conveyed via institutional educational programs and will be posted on a publically accessible website: http://www.hawaii.edu/himb/faculty/grau.html.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The regulation of salt and water balance, or osmoregulation, is fundament to the proper function of the molecules that carry on the business of life.  A failure in osmoregulation is a contributing factor to pathologies of nearly every organ system and the maintenance of salt and water balance in critically ill patients has been identified as one of the most difficult problems for practitioners of internal medicine. A critical component of the systems involved in osmoregulation are the receptors, osmoreceptors, that detect changes in salt and water balance and initiate appropriate responses throughout the body.  Nevertheless, our understanding of how osmoreceptors work has been slow to come because of their typically complex structure and arrangement among other cells in the brain, kidney, gut and elsewhere. This has made the development of appropriate experimental models extremely difficult.  The prolactin cell of the tilapia solves this problem. Although prolactin was initially described as a hormone that promotes lactation in mammals, prolactin has a great variety of actions in vertebrates. In fish, it enables them to adapt to fresh water by preventing ion loss and water entry across the gills and body surface. Unlike mammals, including humans, prolactin cells in tilapia and other bony fish are arranged into a nearly homogeneous mass making it easy to study in the animal and in culture. By employing this model in this project it was further demonstrated that the prolactin cell is an osmoreceptor, which responds directly to changes in osmotic concentration with a change in prolactin secretion which activates the osmoregulatory mechanisms that restore salt and water balance. In this project, in vivo and in vitro experiments were conducted primarily by using dispersed prolactin cells of the tilapia acclimated to fresh water or seawater. With the present project, the mechanisms by which prolactin are synthesized and secreted were studied. Cellular and molecular approaches were employed to elucidate these mechanisms, which involve calcium entry into cells through stretch gated channels and the activation of water channels. During the duration of the project we published 22 manuscripts, trained 1 assistant researcher, 2 postdoctoral fellows, 3 graduate students, 7 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student. Both post-docs and the assistant researcher subsequently obtained tenure-track jobs. A local workshop, the Pauley summer program, was also organized to foster networking opportunities between 30 international collaborators including faculty and students. Further dissemination of work took place through classes, guided visits to research facilities and synergy with other projects, including the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) funded project titled Exploring our Fluid Earth: NOAA Ocean Science Curriculum, Teacher Professional Development and Public Outreach. Knowledge generated by this project produced a broad impact on extending the principles of osmoregulation that are relevant to clinical medicine. Outcomes derived from the project have also provided key information on salinity tolerance in fish species that are commercially important for aquaculture. These studies have offered graduate and undergraduate students an interdisciplinary and collaborative learning environment while benefiting underrepresented minorities, such as native Hawaiians, and have strengthen the national and international collaborative efforts in this field.
